instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message:
The macbook entered wet and with sulfate in this area:

[ATTACH type="full" width="338px"]60627[/ATTACH]

It has been cleaned, I replace the components and now there is no chime: green - orange led, cpu heats up and there is usb activity.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.57V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> = 20.30V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 20.30V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.43V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.33V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5.15V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> = 5.15V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 5.15V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.33V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 3.33V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3.33V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> = 3.33V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 3.33V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_FET</SIGNAL> = 5.15V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_FET</SIGNAL> = 3.33V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> = 1.06V
VCORE = 1.70V

Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message:
If you have USB activity for sure, do PRAM reset.
This should bring chime back.

Did you test external video?

Do you get 5V at pins 28-30 of J8300, in the first few seconds at least?
<SIGNAL>LCD_HPD_CONN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> should go high at same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message:
PRAM RESET but still the same.

No signal on external monitor.

<SIGNAL>LCD_HPD_CONN</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> = 0V

In power supply, the current goes from 0.02V up to 0.95A directly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message:
Do you really have USB activity?
Flashing macOS pendrive, not just power.
What about <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message:
I know there is USB power because it charges my phone and I was able to turn on a UV lamp.

<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 0.00V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message:
USB power is not the same as USB activity!!!
Your board can't have activity, if <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> stays low.
I wouldn't ask you for external video, or PRAM reset, if you didn't say to have USB activity.

Check pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message:
Sorry for delay .


<SIGNAL>CPU_VR_READY</SIGNAL>  - 1.05 V and  <SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is 1.02V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message:
You may have crap accumulated under PCH/CPU.
Try heating with quality flux.
